segments.text: Okay.
He was the first captain, they call it, at West Point, which is the parallel to the cadet colonel at A&M.
He was one of the youngest colonels promoted in World War II, and very young brigadier general, all that, very outstanding all the way.
Commanded the division at a young age, and commanded a corps.
I think that General Westmoreland was a fine commander.
I think that few people would have done it much differently or any better than he did his job that he was assigned.
The mission he was given, I simply think he was given the wrong mission.
I think he was not ever given an objective, a realistic objective.
The national leadership
never defined an objective to win the Vietnam War.
General Westmoreland, like a good soldier, accepted his instructions and carried them out the best he could.
I, in retrospect, have often thought since what difference might have been made if he and he must have realized that

we couldn't win under the rules he was required to operate under what would have been the result if he'd said give me a definitive objective for winning this war that would win this war or give me new orders get me out of here I think it would have made a difference now I'm not saying that I feel he should have done that
I don't know what I would have done under these circumstances.
Sure.
If you're a good soldier and think you can carry out the instructions that have been given you, unless you violently disagree with those instructions, you do the best you can with them.
Sure.
If you violently disagree and can't resolve the difference with your directing authority, then you resign.
You quit.
Ask to be moved.
Transfer.
Now, you dealt with him on a weekly basis.
What kind of person was he?
Well, he was a personable man.
He was intense in the sense that he was always thinking of the mission.
He was always trying to be helpful.
He never showed discouragement to me or to us.
He may have been discouraged at times.
We weren't discouraged.
We won all our battles, and I think it's safe to say that the American forces won their major battles.
There's a lot of talk of the Tet Offensive of 68.
I wasn't there at that time, but the enemy didn't win that battle.
But of course we lost the war.
But General Westmoreland was, he was basically good to work for and
And we appreciated seeing him when he'd come around.
He always had something cheerful or helpful to say.
What did you think of him when you sat down and thought of him?
I think that they had great respect for him.
Because I worked with General Westmoreland after he and I came back from Vietnam.
I was chief of legislative liaison for the Department of the Army, and I saw a great deal more of him then.
And I've seen him several times since he retired.

And I commented to him, looking back not so much on his time in the Vietnam War, but his problem in being chief of staff of the army when the national resolve was melting and the problems were mounting in the army as a result of the lack of resolve to prosecute that war.
I felt, and I told him, I thought he'd had the toughest job as Chief of Staff of the Army as any Chief of Staff ever had, with the possible exception of the Civil War Chiefs of Staff.
You recall that during that period that he was Chief of Staff, for example, the draft was discontinued, which is evidence of the
discontent within the population.
Well, that's taking a means away from the Army, a resource away from the Army.
The Congress, which at the time when I first became chief legislative liaison, I would say that 80% of the members of Congress in 1968 were resolved to prosecute that Vietnam War.
I would say that by the end of 1970, they were a minority.
So the whole thing was crumbling.
It was inevitable we had to just move out.
We had to give up.
That's what happened.
What about the relations with your Vietnamese counterparts?
I'm glad you asked that, because it's occurred to me we should weave this in.
We worked closely with a particular division, the 22nd Division.
It had two commanders, different commanders, while I was there in that year and a half.
We, at times, worked with other divisions.
To generalize a little bit here, when we arrived there, they were pretty well whipped, to some degree demoralized.
I think they've had a lot of experience in combat.
They've been fighting for a long, long time.
But they never really lost their defensive mentality.
We did work side by side in a number of operations, and we did encourage them to do more of the
operations, offensive operations, we never, at least the ones I saw, never got the Vietnamese units in an offensive frame of mind.

I don't know how this should have been balanced out or how it could have been balanced out, but as a result, initially the year and a half I was there, and the front year and a half of this after the buildup,
We just took it upon ourselves to defeat the enemy.
And we did not push these Vietnamese enough into the offensive operations.
I think their greatest weakness was one that we never really came to correct.
Their greatest weakness was their ability to sustain themselves in the field.
In other words, a logistics, lack of logistical know-how and capabilities.
And of course, that is very essential.
Sure.
Arvin didn't have that ability.
They just didn't have that ability.
And it was never developed.
Now, why or how it could have been done better, I don't know.
While you're there basically to conduct combat operations, how can you there at the same time
retrain these divisions of the Vietnamese effectively.
Perhaps there's been a lot of criticism that we didn't give them a greater role.
Well, to give them the greater role, you'd have to prepare them for a greater role.
That was never really accomplished.
And I suppose a part of that was overall resources and capability to support logistically.
because we were strained in supplying that operation over there logistically from our shores here.
So, you know, if you put more over to the Vietnamese, are the American troops going to get enough?
You see what I mean?
Sure.
Well, when you went out on a maneuver, let's say you were going to attack a position, would you take the urban troops with you or would you just do it on your own?
Well, we would do it on our own.
combined with them in an operation, it would be they'd have their area of operation and we would have ours.
And then your air mobile would take care of both?
We would often support them with airlift jets, with aircraft.
Or they'd have a mission that was compatible with their capabilities, you see.
And I must add that they fought some very effective, some good battles
I don't remember the figures, but I recall two or three real successful fights that that particular division had, but it wasn't often they really got engaged like that.
For the most part, they'd sort of sit back at the base?
They tended to protect their territory and not gather up a concentration of force to go and conduct an offensive operation of any duration.
How about the officers?
How'd you get along with the Airmen officers?
Oh, we got along well with them, and some of them were extremely capable officers.
After all, remember the experience they've had now, and that they had had.
For example, the second division commander that I knew in this particular division was a very young man and very bright and had a very positive command presence.
Seemed to be very much respected by his troops, and a capable leader, and a good tactician.
Of course, a number of them were trained in our schools, and a lot of them were trained in the school experience.
But again, they were largely defending themselves.
That's my picture of it.
Of course, a lot of people have complained about the corruption in Vietnam.
Did you find any of this, any experience with that whatsoever?
I had no direct knowledge of that.
I've heard the same thing.
I've heard them over there.
I would like to know what the direct evidence might be, but I think it's safe to say that

It has been the long, long, it's been the custom and tradition in the oriental societies that persons in authority are going, it's almost, if I understand it correctly, it's almost an accepted practice that everyone in authority is a percentage man.
I've heard it said, and I can't prove this, that if an individual becomes
comes in a position of authority in an oriental society, and he has a friend who wants a job and he gets him a job, that friend expects that he should be rewarded.
And so he rewards him.
If you're in the army and you procure from a source, something like supplies, let's say,
If I understand the tradition correctly, and I never saw this, I've never seen it written, then it's sort of common that there is a consideration because, you know, I came to you.
I don't know.
Because you didn't see it.
I didn't see it.
I don't know.
I've heard these things.
But what I'm saying is it's more a part of the system than it is...
identifying with a corrupt Vietnamese army.
It's more a part of the culture.
Okay, would you compare the quality of the North Vietnamese Army with the American Army, just the soldiers?
Well, the North Vietnamese soldier individually is a very good soldier.
In fact, his small units, I'm talking about squads and platoons, fought very well.
I don't believe they ever defeated a company-sized unit of ours or greater.
So you've got to say they don't compare at the higher level.
And I don't want to take any of the credit from that individual Vietnamese soldier, because he usually operated with pretty sparse supplies.
And he wasn't too well equipped.
He had a good rifle, the infantry soldier did.
and they were well disciplined.
I don't want to take away from that either, but they have a form of discipline that, of course, we have, I think, acceptable discipline, but I refer to theirs as the pistol discipline.
But you have to kind of respect any system that will maintain a discipline in those conditions.
Well, the pistol discipline is, as far as I know,
an officer in charge has got the authority of his pistol if he needs that.
That's what I was referring to.
Okay.
You said that most of your combat was with the North Vietnamese Army.
What about the Viet Cong, the indigenous South Vietnamese who were communist-bound?
The Viet Cong, we did have contact with them on a number of occasions because they had
a very well-known regiment that was operating in the area that we were in, and of course, it's hard to visualize the vastness of this area and the fire station, and so when you wonder how

A regiment can survive all the attacks that we made upon them, but part of their mission was survival, of course, because they wanted to choose the moment and type of operation they might conduct to hurt us, disrupt us, keep the system disrupted.
But they seemed to be good soldiers.
Again, they were very effective in avoiding destruction, although I think we had them and...
The two Vietnamese divisions in our area, North Vietnamese division, we had them at times, according to the intelligence we got, in very, very poor strength.
They lost a lot of people, but they always got replaced.
Was there a lot of hatred between the American soldier and the Vietnamese?
I mean, were there?
Which Vietnamese?
The North or the South?
I mean, the North Vietnamese.
The North Vietnamese?
Oh, I think so.
I think it's naturally a hatred of the enemy.
Was it as bad as between the Americans and the Japanese?
I don't believe so.
I don't believe it was.
Because, well, I just don't think it was.
The Japanese, you know, started out their war to not take prisoners and not to be taken in.
Well, what about the idea of Americans not being taken prisoner by the North Vietnamese or the Viet Cong?
We had quite a number taken.
I say we, the armed American forces, compared to the war against the Japanese.
Now in our division, I think we could count them probably on one or two hands that we lost the prisoner status.
And it usually was a case of being overrun, small unit.
Did they ever return?
I never knew of them.
I never knew of the recovery or return.
I would say we could count on one hand.
I remember one incident where we lost two men.
It's when a position was overrun at night.
And there were two or three isolated incidents of where we thought they were taken prisoner.
It's awfully hard to tell once you lose a man whether he was taken prisoner
or just taken off and killed or, you know, what.
Whether he survived prisoner status is what I'm saying.
Sure, absolutely.
What about the Viet Cong were well known in South Vietnam for the amount of terrorism against government officials in the small villages and cities.
Did you ever witness any of the terrorism in Vietnam?
I never actually witnessed it, but I've been close to it.
The Viet Cong used a lot of their, this regiment I mentioned and its battalions,
used a lot of their time.
That's why they wanted to survive, because that was their main function.
They'd go into villages and terrorize them at night, and the purpose was not only the retribution against the leaders, but to keep the people uncertain about our side.
They established the example, well, those guys can't protect you, really.
Right.
One of the things about the American military was one of the criticisms made even by some of the American military themselves was that there was a lot of careerism among the officer corps in Vietnam.
Would you address that?
That is probably a justified criticism because I personally
never favored that.
But it's criticism against the policy, not necessarily the individual.
It was the basic policy, of course, that we'd rotate each after a year of service in Vietnam, officers and enlisted men.
Now there were exceptions.
Volunteer to stay and others were told to stay, like I was asked to stay.
And under those circumstances you volunteer.
And it was generally the practice that officers in command, colonels and below, would be six months, approximately six months in command.
And to me, that was a mistake.

It made some sense to rotate the captains commanding companies that frequently considering they're going to be there one year because of the greater exposure and the greater stress on captains at company level.
I'm talking about infantry captains and cavalry captains.
But it just didn't make any sense at all to me.
I didn't think it was fair to the units of the men to have a
a commander move in every six months and start over.
I thought they should be there their full year.
And there's a lot to be said for leaving the captains too because really if the troopers are going to be there a year, the captain ought to be there a year on that basis.
There's a lot to be said for
leaving them all there for a year.
Okay.
That was a practice, but I never agreed with the six-month rotation for in command.
Another, of course, of the big issues was how the press, the dealings between the military and the press, and many a charge that the press spectacularized the war.
Did you have any relations or dealings with the press?
I sure did.
In fact, this disturbed me a great deal.
And I guess we naturally make the comparisons with the press coverage in World War II, where, first of all, there was censorship.
And there's a lot to be said to justify censorship.
And I think if we ever get into- World War II.
And World War II.
And if we ever get into another conflict, I think we ought to very seriously consider putting it on.
Because you can just look at the Vietnam War,

perspective of time and focus on the press coverage and you can see the influence the comfort to the enemy the influence for the toward deterioration of troop morale and citizen support for that war but anyway that's true about sensationalizing and another feature of World War II you'd expect to have a correspondent with you and he'd stay with you for months and months and months
the division I'm talking about.
And he became known to the men and he knew them and he would understand what that division was doing and accomplishing and so forth.
It was quite different in Vietnam.
We had one man that stayed with us over six months.
And he was representing some little outfit that, of course, he never got many of the headlines in the big papers or on television.
And that's why none of them would want to come and stay with us.
But when they'd get a rumor of a big operation, they'd start showing up.
Of course, we were obligated to give them transportation.
Usually it's air transportation in our outfit.
So you had to take them with you onto the battlefield?
Oh, yes.
Or if you got into a big fight and there was a lot of smoke and fire and blood and casualties, boy, they'd come pouring in.
And where they wanted to be,
was where the fire and smoke and blood was.
Because that's the way they'd get time on TV and a byline in the press.
And I guess you can't blame the individual.
He's competing.
But the thing that upset me was that there was no one, no one in prominence,
in the media, representing the media, who was in any way really tying together the actions we were in or that our corps was in or that all the effort in Vietnam was involved in.
What it really amounted to in many ways was that our people back home were fed news-wise primarily
horror and disasters and failures and that just doesn't make any sense.
Did your commanders or Westmoreland, did they have any comments on this?
I'm sure they did.
I have personally, I've discussed this with many of the people.
What's the team?
Kovacs, somebody in Kovacs in the Washington Post?
That's his name.

Anyway, people like him and the Allsop, Stuart Allsop, and I could name others if I could just be nimble enough to think, would come over about once every six months and refurbish their expertise so they could go back home and write critical articles.

I'd often ask them why their or their press service or their TV network didn't send somebody to try to get a picture of this whole war and they'd always say you can't get on the nightly news with that kind of stuff you can't get on the front page of that kind of stuff what does that say about American society
It says to me that our free press in time of war has to be controlled on the battle area.
There's no doubt in my mind.
Now, I'm not saying don't report the smoke and fire and blood, but I'm saying report it all.
Somehow, get full information to the people.
I don't mean full detail, but full perspective.

And if you can't get that, I think under any circumstances, you've got to have censorship not to primarily to see that our people back home aren't influenced improperly, but primarily to deny the enemy the benefit of the kind of reporting that occurred in Vietnam.
It's just not a fair thing to do.
to our troops.
Speaking of your troops, what about the quality?
You said a little bit earlier that you wanted to talk about the quality of the enlisted men and the soldiers under your command and their morale.
Would you address that?
You bet.
Now, keep in mind that we were, in a way, a special outfit.
We had been formed and trained, organized and trained to be a test division with a brand new concept.
And it turned out to be a dramatic thing.
Most of those men who trained with us came overseas with us.
They were very well trained.
Even though a lot of them were draftees, because you see,
they would have been brought into the division and still had at least a year to do.
If they did still have a year to do, they went with us.
So that's why I say most of the men who came over with us.
The average age of these troopers was down in the low 20s.
Some of our senior non-coms were, of course, past 30.
And most of our officers were 40 or under, of course.
But we had trained them.
And I was very proud of them.
I thought that they were just as splendid soldiers.
I never saw in World War II.
I wouldn't say that, I would say that the courage and the capabilities of our soldier in Vietnam would match
the first year in World War II.
Now I say the first year in World War II because in World War II there was no rotation.
Everybody became better and better and almost automatic.
It didn't become a casualty to build that unit.
And there were cheerful soldiers.
Then in Vietnam, at the end of the first year
Of course, by the end of the first year, we'd lost a number of casualties, and also those who remained were eligible to go home.
Some volunteered to remain.
But practically all the old team, so to speak, left on rotation and were replaced.
I think it was my good fortune that I remained for another six months.
And one of the reasons, of course,
was the one general officer who could remain and see this transition and training of the new people, because General Kennard had a big job to come back to.
And the replacements were mostly young people, and I thought they were, you couldn't have asked for better replacements.
You have the natural problem
of getting everybody back up into good teamwork and training.
We were engaging units of divisions, extremely tough operations in many cases, and they just measured up splendidly.
It hurts me to hear the Vietnamese veteran or the soldier in Vietnam
criticized and blasphemed and really I just can't believe that after I'd been there a year that things fell apart and became so different.
Because the same kind of people were there for the next year and a half.
Same kind of people.
I think we've done a great disservice because
We all became so unhappy with that war that we let that unhappiness reflect on the troops that were fighting that war.
Now, I wasn't there to see that the dope problem became so big.
I think we've had a lot of talk about the grenading by the soldiers of their sergeants or their officers.
I just don't know the statistics on that.
But I'd bet my last dollar that they were magnified beyond the true dimensions by quite a lot.
We knew when our division settled into the base at On Kay, we immediately knew through our CID agents that heroin, for example, was being made available right there in that
It was coming in from outside.
The opportunities were there.
I'm sure all forms of dope.
And we just, our commander told that leadership of that community, if this becomes a problem, these troops will never be allowed in your city.
And by golly, I think they very effectively got a hold of it.
in the Army has the capability to keep up with these things pretty well.
We kept up with it, I think, quite well.
You didn't have a drug problem.
We didn't have a drug problem that we were aware of.
Apparently marijuana became more significant as time went on.
We were not aware of a problem, and I believe we would have been.
The division commander has too many sources
that are looking out for these things for him, for him to go through a period of that much time in ignorance on it.
I'm referring to my division commander.
I commanded that division for a month on a temporary occasion when the commander was out of the country, but I'm referring to our assigned division commander.
I don't believe that
the drug problem ever caused us to lose casualties significantly.
It just never came to our attention.
How about the problems of the guerrilla warfare versus the problems of a linear war, World War II, conventional war?
Did you adapt very well to those problems?
Who's the enemy, for example?
Things that lead to my lies.
Yeah.
Me lie was, some would say it was an aberration.
It was really unquestionably a deliberate event.
It was a...
clearly an atrocity of war.
Incidentally, you mentioned that, so I'll say a few things about it.
I was not there.
No, of course not.
It was in a division commanded by a good friend of mine, by the way.
Who's that?
John Sam Costner, contemporary and a good friend of mine.
I was chief related liaison when Eli happened and

And I got the first letter from this young fella riding Uber, who wrote the letter to the Chief of Staff of the Army, Secretary of Defense, and Chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, in which he, as I recall, it was over two pages typewritten, in which he passed on what a friend of his, a friend who had
had been his friend in training in the States, and they went to separate units in Vietnam and then met over there.
And this friend told him about that incident.
And this young fellow, Ridenhoover, I think his name was, felt his conscience demanded that he inform the authorities on it.
And the first letter received was by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
Representative Mendel Rivers.
And he looked at it and he said, get this over to the back of the Army Legislative Liaison.
I read it and I couldn't believe it, but I had the same reaction.
I better get this to the chief of staff.
And I had it in there in a matter of minutes.
And they looked at it, he looked at it, and he said, well, we've got to, we've got to,
look at this and quickly, and he assigned the Inspector General to look into it, and within a matter of days, he established that there was enough fact there that it had to be investigated in detail.
And then, of course, this whole investigation process started.
And I will comment that after it was all over, there were so many people defending Lieutenant Calley
From what I had learned, and I learned subsequently, I was in part in error.

From what I'd learned about this whole process, and I was very closely, of course, concerned with this investigation and abreast of it because of the Congress's interest, that as far as that incident was concerned, Calley was the commander-in-chief because he was the officer in charge, and this piece of ground, there wasn't anybody else
I subsequently learned that his commander knew about what Calley had done.
Medina?
Medina.
Captain Medina.
But he was tried and found innocent of it.
But the fact is, I'm told, by good authority, that he did know about it and that he knew about it when it happened.
So under those circumstances, I felt that Calley wasn't the fall guy for anybody.
It was his initiative.
He was the only one there to control this thing, and he did it.
And he personally killed a lot of those people.
And my view of it is, and I think most people in the Army felt, it's absolutely inexcusable behavior, unacceptable, no matter what the circumstances.
And the American people will never support
an army that uses its capabilities in such a fashion, even on a small scale.
It's just un-American, it's inhuman, it's against the rules of war and everything else.
Anyway, I'm getting way off the subject here.
No, I want your ideas.
What was our general approach here that I'm diverting from?
guerrilla war, the problems of guerrilla war.
Of course, this is one of them.
Did you know of any situations under your command that were similar to this in which you went into a village and mistook?
We had one atrocity that was a crime, at least, that I was aware of.
And again, here's the case of a soldier that had direct knowledge.
His conscience told him he had to report it.
One of our patrols of five men was ordered to leave at night and go patrol a certain area, going on a three-day patrol, and led by a sergeant.
And they left early one evening and were to be gone three days.
And they were out on a
really a reconnaissance to try to see what the enemy was doing in a certain area, quite an area's distance away.
That'd be dangerous.
It is.
But on their way out of this village, taking off on this thing, they kidnapped a young girl and took her with them for their pleasure.
And after the second day, as I recall,
Consciences began to bother and some rumbling apparently.
And the girl was getting in bad shape.
And so one of the men murdered her, killed her, and left her there.
That's the worst that I know of.
And I consider that to be an aberration.
Here's a case where a non-commissioned officer just

had developed a disrespect for these people it had to be that way and so we'll just take one of these gooks with us you know and of course proper justice was done what happened to these they were tried and well there was one man who didn't participate or two one or two who did not participate but the others were court-martialed and given very
report this incident to the division commander of that Vietnamese division I cited a moment ago, because we felt he should know that we knew and that justice would be done.
He didn't know, but we felt that he might have learned it some other way.
But in any case, he should be informed.
But the guerrilla warfare aspect was mainly a disruptor of the civil populace and of the South Vietnamese
of small governing units, basically.
They'd come into these little district headquarters and try to disrupt things, raise cane, kill government employees, and so forth.
In a way, you can look at the whole North Vietnamese and Viet Cong operation as a guerrilla operation because, but I might add, we didn't have a great deal of
contact with that kind of guerrilla.
And therefore, as I've said, we were dealing mainly with uniformed soldiers, so identifying anyone wasn't too difficult.
But we went over there with a very simple set of five rules of engagement that were designed to not shoot innocent people and not shoot up innocent villages.
or to kill innocent people, but to protect our troops.
And they were applied really, tried to, we just leaned over backwards not to hurt innocent people.
And I'm sure in some cases it cost us some casualties, but we felt we had to be conservative on that because it would have been too bad to ever let it get out of hand, you know.
You just don't shoot on fear.
But I said the whole thing, in a sense, could be looked upon as guerrilla operation because these North Vietnamese divisions we were fighting basically were hanging over borders to fight us.
For example, some of our toughest fights were over on the Vietnamese-Cambodian border.
The enemy had his headquarters, his logistics installations, his medical facilities, all of his important support and command elements in the sanctuary across the border.
And they'd infiltrate to put supplies and ammunition and so forth forward for a period of operations.
and then infiltrate the troops and then get them together and then have it us.
Well, we would defeat them.
But you could kill every one of those men and you haven't destroyed that division because the things that make it build, train, and fight are still back there.
And in that sense, the whole thing was, in a sense, a guerrilla operation.
This is when it

course we wanted the worst way in our division with the capabilities we had to be permitted to go across that border between South Vietnam and Laos and South Vietnam and Cambodia and it's just something that was never even the good soldiers you know Westmoreland and all of them just said that's not our guidance is we're not going to do that so just forget it
But we felt we could stop that Ho Chi Minh Trail with our command and support echelons in South Vietnam with our operating combat troops going into Laos and Cambodia.
And with our capability, we could flit around here and there and not ever become pinned down where they could concentrate mass against us.
I might tell you one instance there.
It was during a period that I was in command of the division and we were operating with a brigade over on the Cambodian, very near the Cambodian border, right on the border as a matter of fact.
And the other brigades were back over to the east.
One of our battalions,
This is one of the tragedies of our experience.
Lost an entire platoon, less a squad that had left and moved separately to an ambush.
This means we lost three squads of men, the artillery observer party with them.
It was a total of 30 some odd men, 20 high.
